Yes. I believe they're, they got created fundamentally only two sexes, male and female.
And then when you have someone who has that intersex condition, which is super rare,

But that can be treated as a case by case, just like someone who's born with a club foot or with

Christian theology is that yes, we were made intentionally, but also we're broken by sin,
meaning like all different parts of our body are affected by that. Not just, you know,
our desires, but also physically affected. Yeah. Yep. Yep. Okay. Okay. So that's a good,
I think that's understanding. And we, and so when we say, um, you know, how you present gender,
what we then mean is not male or female, but masculine or feminine. Um, and that's the,
that's that question and people can be more or less masculine or feminine. And every culture

is we, we have to be aware that there's a cultural aspect to it. Um, we have to be aware that there
is a, um, there are choices to be made. And, and I mean, it's, especially in our culture, um,
is for women, especially what is considered or acceptably feminine is huge. Um, clothing wise,

you know, we're going to this certain event. Let's say her husband said, we're going to go out on a

meant. Um, now that's a separate conversation, what she would do, but that's not, that's not what
I was. But she would, she would know like, if I'm going to do that, like if I'm going to,
if I decide I do want to do that, exactly. Like who are you and what have you done with my husband?
That's what you would say. But the, um, uh, but if he did, she would probably not show up in,
you know, sweat pants and Crocs like, um, because she would, although like she normally,

But no one had any questions about that because culturally it was appropriate for men to wear a

changes throughout time. Um, and so I think there's a lot of different complications to that. And I
think it's healthy that we can have those complications and conversations. I do think
we face a potential issue and people are intentionally, um, being, uh, I don't know if
dishonest is the word they would use, but, but it expressing themselves as a gender,

biblically we might wrestle with. And I think we would have to wrestle with, but I,
but all of this to say it's not clearly defined as sin that isn't. And it's not ever
are people who are even making those choices described as being hated by God. Right. Right.
And in my mind, that still comes back to a key like, and therefore should not, by the way,
therefore should not be hated by God's people. Right. And they should not be hated by Christians.
That's not going to work. I've done a very poor job of that. Yes. And again, I can even understand
how someone listening to our conversation might go like, but that feels kind of like
why do we, why is it that, um, that the church has done such a poor job? Is it because of a

why, why have we struggled so much with treating people who struggle with homosexuality or

I mean, yeah, I would, I've got a couple as well immediate that I think, I think one is
that I think Christians are sometimes more concerned about how they feel about a behavior
than, than about how God feels about a behavior where God would say about that behavior.
And so I think there is to some degree, and you know, I was going to say maybe it's natural.
I don't know exactly, but you know, there's, there is, it costs you something when your child,
is engaging in certain sinful behaviors or making certain sinful choices. Yeah. That's a,
you know, maybe that's part of it is that they're like, well, does this mean I'm not going to get

like Christians do behave more hateful or inappropriate towards certain sins
than others. I don't know the answer to that question. I would only have guesses. Yeah.
What are your thoughts? I mean, why we get their reputation for it. We can come back to that in a

you know, they've, they've built up what it means to stand for truth into something that is reactive

it's like, yeah, that, that is a lot harder in some situations just to be like, wow, like
you identify as transgender. Tell me your story. Like what, um, what is your experience been? How

it's not, um, it's not denying truth to sit there and listen to someone.
Right. And yet sometimes Christians think that for some reason. Um, I don't know, but anyway,

I think that's great. I think we're just, we're trying to kind of engage with this, this

for picking on certain things, um, does have a lot to do with though. Also the kind of what we would

happens is, and really it started during the romantic era, which was a couple of hundred

Well, that was the push in the romantic era. And Christians came along and said, no, no,

And, and the Christian view was, we didn't bring this up. We didn't change. We've had the same

revolting against this. And when we try to defend ourselves, the response or defend our view,

what happens is you create that pattern over and over again, which is, okay, marriage is between a

So I think it's a mixture of all of it. I think sometimes there's an unfair. One of my questions
I love to ask when someone says, why do Christians hate certain people or hate certain things,
is I just ask, like, I would love to hear about your experiences. Can you tell me about when

for two reasons. One, if there is such a story, I really would like to know about it. Like, I really

the things I want us to know when we're engaging in that conversation is I want us to know what

That's awesome. That's really good. Just when it comes to, you know,

Thoughts?
I think because so many of these conversations are identity questions and core for the individuals
who are asking them. So that's why I mentioned identity at the beginning. But I think
when you're either wrestling with something that feels like an identity or you are making decisions

my identity and who Christ says that I am and therefore what he requires of me and the identity

God or God's people are rejecting something about myself. And I think anytime somebody feels like

said, it feels like an identity level thing like this is me, it feels like me, that that conversation
I agree is if somebody if somebody pushes you away, or someone someone challenges or
disagrees with the decisions you're making when it feels like more than just behavior.
Yeah, that that makes you want to push them away. It makes you want to protect yourself from them.
And it's hard to it's hard to engage with the conversation from a but but what if this
is actually a better decision for me. And that's hard to have that conversation for any of us.
And I think that's true for anybody who loses something key. You know, if I mean, if one of

with God is like, why would you take something from me? That is so core to who I am. And I think

Oh, God, son, I'm linking on his name, the guy who you referenced earlier, Sam Allbury,
Allbury. I keep wanting to put an apple in his name. Appleberry, Allberry. And I think it's one
of the interesting things about reading his stuff is that in the midst of the wrestling match,

no one wants to when you feel rejected. No one likes to be somewhere where we feel rejected.
For sure. And I think what we're saying is it isn't rejection.
But we also understand that it does feel like that sometimes.
Yeah. Yeah.
And that's hard.
I think the other piece that we have to really be careful with as Christians is
just the whole conversation about our identity, our feelings forming us. And I think, I think one
thing that's been helpful to me just doing a lot of reading on a lot of these topics and just
listening to people's stories and whatever is going back to the conversation that none of us

day. They can't be truth for us because our feelings are misleading. And I think that's a piece

or it's not best for you. And everything within us feels like that isn't true. I think trusting
hard. And I think acknowledging that is helpful, but also like when we're in a culture that's saying

story and says, Hey, my best for you may really go against the way you feel sometimes that creates a
lot of confusion or deconstruction in us to to kind of wrestle with that, I think.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email at info

Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
